Hand washing and the use of disinfectant gels and sprays are commonly recommended and perceived as sufficient hygiene measures to eradicate Salmonella and any other potential pathogens.
14, 15 However, these hygiene methods, as generally practiced, do not provide reliable protection against diverse amphibian- and reptile-borne contaminants.
14, 15 Indeed, the use of these materials and methods may generate undue over-reliance and misplaced confidence in personal disease prevention and control that may lead to infection as a result of complacency.
